Problem:
Consider a function defined as \\(z(t) = \int_0^t e^{i\omega s} x(s) \, ds\\), where \\(x(t)\\) represents the input signal and \\(e^{i\omega s}\\) is a complex exponential function used for frequency analysis. The transformation aims to filter or modify the frequency components of \\(x(t)\\).

If an additional modulation \\(x(t) = x_0(t) \cdot e^{i\eta t}\\) is applied to the input signal at a time \\(t_1 < T\\), where \\(\eta\\) is a constant, will \\(z(T)\\)'s predominant frequency component still be \\(\omega\\)?
Explanation: The intervention by the modulation with \\(e^{i\eta t}\\) shifts the frequency spectrum of the input signal. Thus, the major component of frequency in \\(z(T)\\) will now be a summation or difference between \\(\omega\\) and \\(\eta\\), rather than just \\(\omega\\), thereby affecting the output spectrum at time T.
